item.title: Built to Last
item.description:
When I was fifteen, my dad bough me my first guitar, a Tanglewood dreadnought style acoustic. Last year I brought it over to Poland so I could play it again. I‚Äôve had it over half my life now, and it‚Äôs still going strong. It‚Äôs showing signs of age and breakdown but it will keep going and may well outlive me (even though it‚Äôs not really alive).

I think about my guitar and other long-lasting tech when I consider most modern technology. With my recent reading of Perennial Seller and the upcoming Apple event, there is a lot of buzz over upgrades and the debates over what device to get. I‚Äôm looking at upgrading my phone from an iPhone SE to probably the iPhone X(s?). I want a smaller phone but one that has the best internals so it will keep going for a while.

I don‚Äôt really need this upgrade, my iPhone SE still works really well, the iOS 12 beta has made it much faster and more responsive and is like a processor upgrade, and the battery still lasts a good amount of time (and could be upgraded). Despite these factors, a new iPhone is still probably the best idea.

My wife has my old iPhone 5s and its battery is not doing so well, in addition we have just become parents and I‚Äôd love her to be able to take live photos as well. I‚Äôm also worried that the security updates will eventual stop coming for the 5s.

To be far to Apple, their software updates do help their devices last much longer than the average phone company, and the proliferation of battery replacement recently has helped devices last longer, still I know for sure that even the latest iPhone won‚Äôt outlast me.

Last year I bought an old hassleblad 500cm, a medium format film camera. It‚Äôs from the year I was born and it‚Äôs going strong. I can bet it will still be going strong in 30 years time.

item.title: Ideas are Cheap
item.description:
Another idea from perennial seller by Ryan Holiday, ideas are cheap, executing really matters. So many people have a ‚Äúgreat idea for a book‚Äù but a tiny fraction of those people actually even start writing (and then an even smaller fraction finish. It‚Äôs completely true and one of the key changes I made in my early twenties was moving from having ideas to trying out ideas. Later in my twenties I started getting better at finishing those same ideas and not just starting a whole host of new ones. However, that is still a skill I need to develop.

I did think of James Altchure‚Äôs idea factory habit (habit two). He seeks to be a constantly thinking of ideas AND reviewing them to only take action on the best ones. While ideas are cheap, we also need ideas.

Finally I remembered Dan Aierly who described how people want to be given credit for their ideas more than the actions they take. I can certainly relate and I believe that‚Äôs related to why the statement that ‚Äúideas are cheap‚Äù is so tough to stomach. We want recognition for our ideas, we believe they are valuable, but in reality no one rewards you just for ideas, they reward people for carrying out their ideas.

item.title: No, you shouldn't spend 4/5th of your time marketing and 1/5th creating
item.description:
I‚Äôm listening to ‚Äùperennial seller‚Äù by Ryan Holiday and early on he takes aim at this truism that‚Äôs been going around. spend 1/5th of your time creating and 4/5ths promoting. He said it sounds good but really if your products not up to snuff then you‚Äôre trying to generate interest in something which doesn‚Äôt matter. (Being cynical it could well be that the type of business advisor who passes on this advice knows that their audiences products aren‚Äôt that good).

Anyway I was curious what the biggest companies ad spend to research budget was and if this might inform a better principle/ demonstrate that the 4/5th marketing idea was wrong. So what better place to start than Apple.

Apple ad Spend to RnD

Apple‚Äôs ad spend is now not widely revealed and bundled in with its administrative costs. That‚Äôs because it‚Äôs under 10% of its expenses and so it isn‚Äôt necessary to disclose. The last available figure is from 2015 when it was $1.8 billion. Pretty high, but how did RnD compare in 2015? In fact, in 2015 RnD budget rose by $1.5 billion to aproximaately $5.9 billion. And in 2017 there was a $10 billion RnD spend target. So it‚Äôs possible that Apple spends closer to ten times as much on developing products than marketing them. Even a conservative estimate would argue they spend a reverse 4/5ths on creating and 1/5th on marketing,

General Motors

How about General Motors? Not a one of these modern tech companies but still a form of technology. Well the statistics for 2017 show they spend $3.24 billion on advertising but $7.3 billion on Research and development. That‚Äôs just over twice as much on research than marketing. Again not the four fifths dynamic that was advised.

Amazon

Amazon spent $16 billion on research and development last year and $7 Billion on advertising in 2016. Seeing as amazon also sells products and has a movie streaming service, we could also include the $4.5 billion it spent on acquiring film rights as part of the cost of product vs marketing but regardless, Amazon also spends more on ‚Äúcreating‚Äù than marketing.

Conclusion, spend more time creating than marketing

The conclusion from these companies is clear, you should spend more time creating than marketing. It‚Äôs much easier to market good products than bad ones.

item.title: Good link posts vs bad link post
item.description:
Every now and again I come across someone who is critical of this form of micro blogging. They usually argue that all link posts are bad, but personally I‚Äôve found it to be a mixed bag with higher and lower quality. This means there must be some factors which separate good link posts and bad link posts.

In truth, I think that a good link post is similar to a good blog post, it provides the reader with some for of value. Be that

  • entertainment
  • education or whatever, in every case you feel that you got value from that blog post/link post. In terms of link posts, I can identify three forms of value I get from good link posts.

1. Discovery via one link post

This is where a link is shared and it leads me to an article I wouldn‚Äôt have read before. In a situation like this, simply sharing the link on social media might have the same effect but the link post usually makes it stand out more in my RSS feed.

2. Discovery via the hive mind

This is where a link is shared once and it passes me by, perhaps the topic sounds boring or the title isn‚Äôt very descriptive/interesting. However, soon it seems that everyone is sharing the same links and I finally give into the pressure and try it out. In this case, it might be quote that the final person shares that makes me crack, but again it is usually the fact that something is being linked everywhere rather than how the link post actually is formatted.

3. Commentary

The third category is where someone takes a link but goes further, they add their unique take or insight on the story. Perhaps it is their own story or whatever, regardless, the value in this case is both the original article and the additional commentary. The previous two cases have value in the curation, this last one has value in the link post. That‚Äôs why I usually try and write a link post like this, one which has some additional value or insight. That because I think there is a common trait in bad link posts.

The same old, same old

The common trait in bad posts is that this link post has no value. Either the link doesn‚Äôt pass on value or the commentary doesn‚Äôt. Perhaps it‚Äôs because I‚Äôve come across the article already, the article isn‚Äôt that interesting to me, or the commentary doesn‚Äôt really add anything. In this case the more the article gets linked, the worse quality usually comes with it. It‚Äôs usually the same old talking points and I‚Äôm more likely to have read it or just not be interested in it.

Steal don‚Äôt copy

Another way to put it would be that you should steal (like an artist) and take some else‚Äôs link but not just copy it. Add

  • your own insight,
  • your favourite quote (and why)
  • an experience that was similar (or completely the opposite)
  • what questions you have
  • some related links
  • something else

So basically, make sure you give value with your linking and everyone wins. Or don‚Äôt and just write for you and you‚Äôll be happy anyway.

item.title: Welcome to the World
item.description:
I collapsed on my bed at 2:30 on Wedneday morning after driving home from the hospital. I had been concerned that I wouldn‚Äôt be able to fall a sleep but soon my heavy eyes shut for four hours or so till my morning alarm reopened them.

Four hours earlier my baby girl left her hiding place and entered the world. It‚Äôs an experience which was truly mind blowing and left me speechless and frozen. I‚Äôm not sure anything could have made me properly prepared though.

My daughter has entered a completely different world to the one I did just over thirty years ago. My wife and I were discussing it just the night before that she‚Äôll see incredible things and grow up in a world so removed from our own. She‚Äôll face new challenges (as well as some of the same old ones) and be blessed with new advantages.

For the last few months I‚Äôve known roughly when my daughter would arrive ‚Äì though she did decide to arrive early ‚Äì and with several commitments and invitations I‚Äôve replied that I‚Äôd have to see how things are once she is here. This is continuing as she remains in Hospital.

I‚Äôm fully prepared for all my once existent free time to disappear in a puff of smoke. It‚Äôs certainly made me reevaluate many of the things I‚Äôve been doing. Many of them just don‚Äôt see important in the grand scheme of things now, others seem more fun. It‚Äôs a big part of my change in writing and embracing micro.blog further as well as enjoying drawing and analogue tools more.

Regardless, my plans don‚Äôt focus that much on me anymore. I‚Äôll be adapting to her needs and wants.

I can‚Äôt wait to learn more about her and what she‚Äôs interested in.

item.description:
Yesterday evening I suddenly had a random idea*, could I draw a face with just vertical lines? I grabbed my iPad and Apple pencil and gave it a go to find out that I could indeed draw a face with just verticals lines.

I tried a few combinations and the decided I had gone as far as I could do I‚Äôd try horizontal lines to see the difference. I started drawing and again reached the end after about five variations. I was about to call it quits with a warm glow on my face when I suddenly realised. ‚ÄúVertical lines can be hair!‚Äù

Suddenly a whole host of new options were open to me as hair, then beards and more facial hair became a possibility. Then I realised ears could be shown with vertical lines and even piercings. I had given up to easily and almost missed out on a whole world of extra possibilities by not spending more time thinking and experimenting.

Obviously drawing a face with just vertical lines isn‚Äôt exactly a revolution or really something any of us will need to do on a day to day basis but it was fun and the main lesson ‚Äîto not give up easily and keep exploring an idea ‚Äî is very useful for everyday life.

*I believe this idea was a synthesis of practicing faces based of Activities from @Rohdesign and Austin Kleon

item.title: A Commonplace (book/blog)
item.description:
Have you ever stumbled upon an idea that moved you into action? This last week I did in a minor way after listening to an episode of the sketchnote army podcast with Austin Kleon. In that episode he mentioned the way he was using his notebooks and within a day, I had picked up a new notebook to experiment. Perhaps this idea will inspire you into action as well. Or maybe not.

Creating a commonplace book

Austin shared how he had started carrying a pocket notebook and logging various elements during the day. Later he‚Äôd go back over those pages and highlight the key items and ideas. Eventually, they might turn into a blog post or a book. I had heard him talk about similar notebooking techniques before when he called it a commonplace book. This inspired me to go out, buy a new a6-ish size moleskine and record. I had already been doing something similar at my work desk on pages of A4, but the pocket book had the advantage of being with me not only at my desk but also on the train, when in bed and basically everywhere.

There‚Äôs something charming about keeping an analogue notebook in an increasingly digital world.

the digital commonplace

Of course, the natural extension of this new notebook was to start sharing some extracts online, specifically on micro.blog. It reminded me of the charm of early blogging. When it wasn‚Äôt so serious, when you didn‚Äôt need a specific goal or career from it and mistakes were useful and a sign of growth. You didn‚Äôt (and don‚Äôt) have to present yourself as an expert in something you just started out in.

This digital commonplace book or adversersia had some obvious advantages such as linking to music or videos online as well as sharing items. Even though analogue tools have a charm, digital tools provide some extra functions. Of course, we don‚Äôt have to choose one or another, we can have both.

The need to dig deeper

Keeping this notebook has made me really appreciate deeper content and devalue shallow, entertainment focused items. I want to be clear here, I‚Äôm not saying entertainment is wrong, I‚Äôm not saying you should do or feel the same, this has been my reaction. When reading a book or something of greater depth, material is provided for the commonplace book. A quote here, an idea there, a beautiful graphic to copy. When the material is shallow, repeating the same talking points, then it‚Äôs much rarer for my book to see any difference. I‚Äôve almost gamed myself to want to read more books than blogs.

I had actually been feeling guilty or FOMO about not being to keep up with all the micropodcast that have been starting up (especially with starting one myself. How can I expect people to listen to my own if I don‚Äôt listen to theirs?) but this notebook has helped me deal with that.

We can‚Äôt do every great things, and trying to have it all, result in having nothing.

By trying to keep up with all these podcasts and blogs, I‚Äôm missing out on reading great books. So I‚Äôm making a commitment, to fill my adversaria, to read great books and go deeper.
I keep wanting to ‚Äúlike‚Äù things here‚Ä¶but I don‚Äôt want to favourite them. I‚Äôve been trained not to comment but star on social media and it‚Äôs not easy to untrain yourself.
